metadata.case_name: Appellant Dealers v. Sales Tax Authorities

facts.text: Appellants are dealers registered under the Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946 carrying on business in art silk, cotton and hand loom cloth.

During January 26, 1950 to March 31, 1950, appellants effected sales outside State of Bombay protected by Art. 286(1)(a) of Constitution, outside reach of Act, but Sales Tax Officer assessed turnover and levied tax of Rs. 4,494/3/9.
In appeal, order of Sales Tax Officer affirmed by Assistant Collector of Sales Tax.
Additional Collector of Sales Tax in revision reduced levy and ordered refund of Rs. 2,238/0/6, which was paid to assessees.

Before moving Tribunal in revision, Additional Collector by letter dated May 17, 1958 informed appellants that unless they furnished proof of refunding the amount to purchasers within three months, it would be forfeited under s.12A(4).
Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal by order dated November 26, 1958 allowed appellants' claim in full and directed refund of additional sum of Rs. 2,256/2/6.
During April 1, 1950 to March 31, 1951, appellants effected sales outside State of Bombay; Sales Tax Officer levied tax of Rs. 23,806/3/6 on that turnover.
In appeal, Assistant Collector allowed partial claim, ordered refund of Rs. 12,154/15/- but informed it would be forfeited if not refunded to purchasers.
Additional Collector in revision dated November 1, 1958 ordered further refund of Rs. 3,588/1/9 but Sales Tax Officer did not give effect to it.
Tribunal allowed appellants' claim in full for second period; Revenue's reference to High Court rejected; appellants entitled to refund of Rs. 23,806/3/6.
Despite orders, Sales Tax Officer did not pay refunds and threatened forfeiture under s.12A(4).
On June 27, 1962, Sales Tax Officer called upon assessees to appear on July 2, 1962 with particulars of tax collected from out-of-state purchasers during January 26, 1950 to March 31, 1951.

Appellants filed Special Civil Application No. 641 of 1962 in Gujarat High Court under Art. 226 praying for directions to comply with refund orders and refrain from action under s.12A(4); High Court dismissed by judgment dated November 29 and December 2, 1963.
Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate.

legal_issues.text: Constitutional validity of S.12A(4) of the Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946, whether violative of Art.19(1)(f) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Prayed for directions to respondents to comply with refund orders and refrain from taking action under s.12A(4).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 226 of Constitution; orders of Tribunal and lower authorities

respondent_arguments.text: S.12A(4) is a penal provision incidental to power to tax sales, imposing penalty for contravention of s.12A(1) and (2).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 54 List II; Ram Gopal v. Sales Tax Officer, Surat (Gujarat High Court)

court_reasoning.text: S.12A(4) not a taxation measure as amounts collected not exigible to tax under the Act; similar to provision held invalid in Abdul Quadar case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amount concerned is not a tax exigible under the law but still forfeited; not ancillary to legitimate tax collection.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming penal provision within competence, it violates Art.19(1)(f) as no procedure for enquiry, quasi-judicial determination or opportunity to be heard; arbitrary, unguided power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Penalising without enquiry violates natural justice; no machinery for disputed facts; purely administrative.

court_reasoning.text: No adjudication or order contemplated; doubtful if appealable under s.21; fails reasonableness test under Art.19(5) considering procedural aspects.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restrictions on fundamental rights must be reasonable in substance and procedure.

holdings.text: S.12A(4) of Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946 is void being violative of Art.19(1)(f).

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Quadar and Co. v. Sales Tax Officer, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar provision under Hyderabad Act not ancillary to tax power as amount not exigible.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Gopal v. Sales Tax Officer, Surat
precedents_cited.relevance: Gujarat High Court upheld s.12A(4) but Supreme Court disagrees.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dr. N.B. Khare v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasonableness of restrictions under Art.19 depends on procedural and substantive aspects.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. V.G. Rao
precedents_cited.relevance: Reiterated need to examine both substantive and procedural reasonableness.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions for dealer definition, registration, assessment, returns, recovery; S.12A prohibits collection of tax on exempt sales and forfeits excess collections.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.19(1)(f) guarantees right to property violated by arbitrary forfeiture; Art.286 exempts inter-state sales; Art.226 for writ; Art.19(5) for reasonableness test.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; S.12A(4) declared void as violative of Art.19(1)(f); no need to examine other contentions.
outcome.relief_granted: Constitutional invalidity of S.12A(4); implies protection from forfeiture threats and entitlement to refunds as per prior orders.

key_quotes.text: Penalising a person without an enquiry is abhorrent to our sense of justice. It is a violation of the principles of natural justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reason for invalidity: lack of procedural safeguards.

key_quotes.text: The impugned provision which provides for the forfeiture of the amount in the hands of the dealers, does not lay down any procedure for ascertaining whether in fact the dealer concerned had collected any amount by way of tax.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights absence of enquiry mechanism violating Art.19(1)(f).

key_quotes.text: On a reasonable interpretation of the impugned provision, we have no doubt that the power conferred under S.12A(4) is unguided, uncanalised and uncontrolled. It is an arbitrary power.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Summarizes why provision fails reasonableness test.
